title: Russia-Ukraine Crisis—How To Tell If Pictures And Videos Are Fake
creator: Kate O'Flaherty
Senior Contributor
description: Disinformation around the Russia-Ukraine crisis is rife. Here’s how to tell the real videos and pictures from the fakes.
content: Disinformation around the Russia-Ukraine crisis is rife. Here’s how to tell the real videos and pictures from the fakes.

title: Actor Sean Penn In Ukraine Filming Documentary About Russia Invasion
creator: Sentinel Digital Desk
description: American Oscar-winning actor Sean Pean was spotted in Ukraine’s Kyiv city to record events about the current Russian invasion in Ukraine.
content: NEW DELHI: Amid the military operations in Ukraine by Russia, American actor, director and screenwriter Sean Penn has put himself in the centre of crisis as he has reached Ukraine to record events for documentaries about Russia's invasion.At this moment when Russia has started full-scale on its neighbour, the actor arrived in Ukraine only to record all that is happening in the country so that he can provide a clear picture in front of the world about Russia's invasion in Ukraine. On Thursday 24 February the long-time humanitarian activist and Oscar-winning actor Penn was spotted in Ukraine's capital city Kyiv during a press conference by the Ukrainian government. Penn was seen listening to the government officials of Ukraine speaking about the huge crises due to the Russian attacks. Many global leaders in the press briefing have been regarding the Russian-Ukraine conflict as the worst conflict in Europe since the year 1945. In November last year, the actor visited Ukraine to research and gather the required information for the documentary. According to reports, the 61-year-old actor Penn arrived in Ukraine capita Kyiv in the previous week and had a meeting with Deputy Prime Minister Iryna Vereshchuk. He also met the military members and local journalists in the city dealing with the current situation. In a recent statement issued by the office of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy, it has praised the western actor who gave a special visit to Kyiv to understand the situation and record events to present the truth of the Russian invasion of the country. The statement reads Sean Penn is among those who support Ukraine in the present situation. The country is grateful to him for his honesty and courage in supporting Ukraine at this tough time. The President also stated that the actor through this step demonstrates bravery that many other are lacking mainly the Western politicians. He added that the more people like this, Ukraine's true friend comes forward, the quicker the country can deal with the Russian invasion putting a stop to it. Also read: Sally Kellerman, Original Hot Lips from 'M*A*S*H,' Dead at 84Also watch:

title: Lack of clear guidance is worrying Kerala students stuck in Ukraine to no end
creator: Edex Live
description: Ashra, who is pursuing her education in a centrally-located university in Ukraine, shared how she and other students were worried because there was no guidance in place
content: A medical student from Kerala who is in her 20s, Arundhathi, anxiously spoke to a local TV channel in Ukraine about their limited stock of food and water. They were asked to move to the bunkers of the university hostel as soon as possible and only with their essentials, she said, and added that network coverage might go out anytime.  It is since February 24 that Ukraine has been facing the onslaught of Russia. Via the video call the medical student was making, her and the ordeal of 60 other students who were packed in the congested bunker was obvious. There was very dim light and students were seated on the floor, holding on to their essentials and backpacks.  Arundhathi also shared how huge explosions could be heard and they were extremely concerned about their safety.  Yet another student, Ashra, who is pursuing her education in a centrally-located university in Ukraine, shared how she and other students were worried because there was no guidance in place.  "There are 200-300 students from Kerala alone on our campus. We are not getting any clear guidance on what to do. Initially, we were asked to move to the bunker. When we packed our bags and reached there, our university head asked us to go back to our hostel room. So we came back. Movement is very risky in these times," Ashra said, as quoted in a report by PTI. Two professional students, Swalika and Ameya, are waiting for instructions from authorities with regards to shifting to the nearest bunker. They were told that at any point in time, water and power supply might be halted. They were worried about contacting their families back in Kerala, not being able to withdraw money from ATMs, limited food storage and so on.

title: Former heavyweight boxing champions Vitali and Wladimir Klitschko say they'll go to war for Ukraine against Russia
creator: blane@businessinsider.com (Barnaby Lane)
description: "I don't have another choice, I have to do that. I'll be fighting," said Vitali Klitschko, who is the mayor of Ukraine's capital, Kyiv.
content: Wladimir and Vitali Klitschko.Getty/Richard Heathcote Ukraine's army will be able to call on the services of two former world heavyweight champion boxers. Vitali Klitschko has vowed to join his brother, Wladimir, in fighting for Ukraine against Russia.  "I don't have another choice, I have to do that," Vitali, who is the mayor of Kyiv, said. The former heavyweight boxing champion Vitali Klitschko said he would take up arms alongside his brother and fellow boxing icon, Wladimir, to fight for Ukraine, their home country, against invading Russia.Russian President Vladimir Putin launched a military assault in Ukraine Thursday.Attacks have so far been reported on Ukrainian military targets in the cities of Kharkiv, Kyiv, and Odessa, killing dozens.Vitali, who has been the mayor of Ukraine's capital, Kyiv, since 2014, said he was ready to fight in a "bloody war.""I don't have another choice, I have to do that. I'll be fighting," the former WBO, WBC, and Ring Magazine world heavyweight champion told ITV's Good Morning Britain on Friday."I believe in Ukraine, I believe in my country and I believe in my people."Wladimir, who boasts the second longest reign as a heavyweight champion in boxing history, enlisted in Ukraine's reserve army earlier this month.In a statement made on LinkedIn Thursday, he too said he would fight and urged others to do the same."Democracy cannot defend itself; it needs the will of the citizens, the commitment of everyone," he wrote. "Basically, there is no democracy without democrats."Here, we will defend ourselves with all our might and fight for freedom and democracy. You can also act. Let not fear seize us; let's not remain frozen."The 45-year-old went on to ask the world's governments to impose swift and serious sanctions upon Russia. "This war against my country is not only the result of one man's madness, but also the result of years of weakness in Western democracies," he said."This madness must be stopped now by stepping up deterrents. Our governments need to say things loud and clear."The two brothers also appeared in a joint video calling for international support for the Ukrainian cause.—Michael Benson (@MichaelBensonn) February 24, 2022The Klitschko brothers aren't the only Ukrainian professional boxers affected by Russia's invasion.Vasiliy Lomachenko, a two-time Olympic gold medalist and three-division champion, fled Ukraine for Greece, according to MARCA.WBA, WBO, and IBF heavyweight champion Oleksandr Usyk, who defeated Anthony Joshua in September, was in London this week attending a publicity event for a video game, but returned to Ukraine Thursday."Some wrote to me that I ran away; I didn't, I was at work but I'm back, I'm home," Usyk said in an Instagram video."Friends, we have to unite because it's a hard time right now and I'm really emotional and worry about my country, and our people. Friends, we have to stop this war; all of us together."Read the original article on Insider

title: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle say they 'stand with the people of Ukraine' in new statement
creator: mfriel@businessinsider.com (Mikhaila Friel)
description: It appears to be the first statement issued by members of the royal family about the Russian invasion.
content: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry.Chris Jackson - Pool/Getty Images Prince Harry and Meghan have issued a statement responding to Russia's invasion of Ukraine.  They said they stand with Ukraine against this "breach of international and humanitarian law." They appear to be the first royals to make a statement. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex have issued a powerful message in response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine.Writing in a joint statement on their Archewell website, Prince Harry and Meghan Markle wrote: "We stand with the people of Ukraine.""Prince Harry and Meghan, The Duke and Duchess of Sussex and all of us at Archewell stand with the people of Ukraine against this breach of international and humanitarian law and encourage the global community and its leaders to do the same," a spokesperson for the couple wrote. It appears to be the first statement issued by members of the royal family about the Russian invasion. Russian forces attacked Ukraine with airstrikes and shelling in the early hours of Thursday morning in an invasion that had been feared for weeks, something that President Vladimir Putin called a "peace-keeping operation."As Insider previously reported, Putin recognized two Ukrainian separatist regions — Luhansk and Donetsk — as independent states, calling Ukraine "not just a neighboring country," but also "an inherent part of our history" with "blood and family ties" during a speech on Monday, according to the RT translation.Harry and Markle's statement comes after British Prime Minister Boris Johnson addressed the nation on Thursday. In the statement, Johnson said he offers the support of the UK and condemned Putin's actions."I say to the Ukrainians in this moment of agony, we are praying for you and your families and we are on your side," Johnson said in the video message.Read the original article on Insider

title: Putin ‘has sights beyond Ukraine’ as Russian forces amass on Polish border
creator: James Hockaday
description: 'He's made clear that he'd like to reconstitute the Soviet empire.'
content: Russian forces are already far west in Ukraine, fuelling fears that they could push on across Europe (Picture: Reuters/ABC) Vladimir Putin may push further into Eastern Europe after he takes over Ukraine, US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken has said. The grim warning comes as satellite images show Russians soldiers and artillery building up in the Belarusian city of Brest – just 10 miles east of the Polish border. Moscow is said to have assembled more than 50 heavy equipment transporters at a training area in near the city, according to Pentagon national security reporter Jack Detsch. It has also added more equipment at a nearby railyard, the correspondent for Foreign Policy magazine added. Exactly why Russia has amassed these troops is unclear, but Blinken fears Putin may have goals beyond Ukraine. He told CBS Evening News: ‘You don’t need intelligence to tell you that that’s exactly what President Putin wants. ‘He’s made clear that he’d like to reconstitute the Soviet empire. Short of that, he’d like to reassert a sphere of influence around neighbouring countries that were once part of the Soviet bloc. ‘And short of that, he’d like to make sure that all of these countries are somehow neutral.’ NEW: U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken to @DavidMuir: “Is it a possibility that Putin goes beyond Ukraine? Sure, it’s a possibility.”More tonight on @ABCWorldNews. https://t.co/N6PX4MAjBa pic.twitter.com/AD0zONIFlp— World News Tonight (@ABCWorldNews) February 24, 2022 Attacks have been launched across Ukraine, while forces are amassing near the Belarus/Poland border (Picture: Metro.co.uk) Satellite images show military forces near the western Belarusian city of Brest (Picture: Reuters) Moscow is said to have assembled more than 50 heavy equipment transporters at a training area in near the city (Picture: Reuters) But Blinken said there is ‘something very powerful standing in the way’ of a Russian advancement across Europe. He told ABC news that Article Five of NATO’s founding treaty would mean that an invasion of Poland, Slovakia, Hungary or Romania would automatically drag the US, UK, France, Canada and other members into conflict. Blinken added: ‘An attack on one member of NATO is an attack on all members of NATO. The president has been very clear that we will defend every inch of NATO territory.’ He said this would be the ‘most powerful deterrent’ against Putin stretching his forces beyond Ukraine. But whatever happens, the top diplomat says he is ‘convinced’ that Putin is going to try and overthrow the Kyiv government. Blocks of flats in the Ukrainian capital have been decimated by Russian airstrikes (Picture: AFP/Getty Images) Firefighters battle to put out a blaze as Kyiv suffered its biggest bombardment since World War Two (Picture: Getty Images) A woman is left badly wounded after an airstrike damaged an apartment complex in the city of Chuhuiv, Kharkiv Oblast (Picture: Getty Images) More: US newsBaby orphaned after parents took her to drug party where they died along with three othersMother 'left three-month-old baby with Covid and bleeding lungs in care of brother'Donald Trump says Putin is a 'genius' after 10,000 Russian troops invade Ukraine NATO countries, including the US and the UK, have stressed that they will not send troops into Ukraine, which is not a member of the alliance. As it amassed as many as 190,000 troops along the Ukrainian border in a matter of weeks, Russia continually denied plans to invade. But it demanded legal guarantees that Ukraine is never allowed to join NATO, as it feels the pact has expanded too far eastwards and poses a security threat. While Ukraine has received reports from the alliance’s members and has contributed to NATO missions, it is not immediately close to joining. First Ukraine would need to improve its political and legal systems and rid them of corruption. The country has also faced fighting from pro-Moscow separatists since 2014 – meaning it is far too unstable to be considered for NATO any time soon. Get in touch with our news team by emailing us at webnews@metro.co.uk. For more stories like this, check our news page.

title: Russian tennis star Daniil Medvedev is ‘all for peace’ after Vladimir Putin launches Ukraine invasion
creator: Daniel Austin
description: The Russian invasion of Ukraine has led to protests by citizens in Moscow and St. Petersburg, and Daniil Medvedev says he wants to 'promote peace.'
content: Daniil Medvedev is Russia’s most high profile sports star. (Photo by Daniel Pockett/Getty Images) Tennis world number one Daniil Medvedev says he wants to ‘promote peace’ all around the world after his home nation Russia launched an invasion of neighbouring Ukraine. Russia has spent months amassing soldiers along the Ukrainian border and president Vladimir Putin instigated a full scale violent assault on multiple cities in the early hours of Thursday morning which has drawn furious condemnation from the international community. Some Russian people have reacted with protests in cities including Moscow and St. Petersburg, and various national celebrities have condemned the violence. Now US Open champion Medvedev says he is in favour of peace rather than war. ‘By being a tennis player I want to promote peace all over the world,’ the 26-year-old said after defeating Japan’s Kei Nishikori at the Mexican Open. ‘We play in so many different countries. I’ve been in so many different countries as a junior and as a pro. It’s just not easy to hear all this news. I’m all for peace.’ Last week world number seven and fellow Russia Andrey Rublev partnered with Ukrainian player Denys Molchanov to win the Open 13 Provence at Marseille, and Medvedev says that spirit of collaboration between the nations is the right way forward. ‘This was amazing because I think people need to stay together and that’s the most important,’ Medvedev said, referring to the partnership between the two players. More: TennisNovak Djokovic set to lose world No.1 spot after shock defeat to world No.123 Jiri VeselyEmma Raducanu's stalker is ordered to stay away from her for five yearsNovak Djokovic gives update on potential Indian Wells appearance amid US visa problems ‘In this moment, you understand that tennis sometimes is not that important. It was definitely not easy to play and I am happy that I managed to win the match. That was a little bit of a roller-coaster day.’ Rublev, meanwhile, is playing in a singles tournament in Dubai and spoke of the pain he feels about the situation facing Ukraine. ‘In these moments you realise that my match is not important. It’s not about my match, how it affects me. What’s happening is much more terrible,’ he said. ‘You realise how important [it] is to have peace in the world and to respect each other no matter what, to be united. It’s about that. We should take care of our earth and of each other. This is the most important thing.’ Zverev kicked out of Mexican Open after hitting umpire’s chair in furious rage ‘I was humiliated!’ – Djokovic slams Australian Open interview after vaccine comments For more stories like this, check our sport page. Follow Metro Sport for the latest news on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.

title: Hollywood actor making documentary in Ukraine
creator: RT
description: Actor Sean Penn is reportedly in Ukraine making a documentary for VICE News about Russia’s military operation in Ukraine Read Full Article at RT.com
content: Sean Penn plans to document the Russian military operation Hollywood actor and director Sean Penn is reportedly on the ground in Ukraine filming a documentary about Russia’s ongoing military operation there. The 61-year-old is making the film in association with VICE World News and Endeavor Content, according to a VICE spokesperson, who declined to provide any further details about the project. Penn arrived in Kiev on Thursday to “tell the world the truth about Russia’s invasion” of its neighbor, with the Office of the President of Ukraine announcing the actor’s arrival. Penn was seen at a press briefing in the presidential office in Kiev on Thursday, and was also briefly featured in an Instagram story posted by Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Volodymyr Zelenskyy/Instagram The Ukrainian government has expressed gratitude to Penn, writing in a statement: “The director specially came to Kyiv to record all the events that are currently happening in Ukraine and to tell the world the truth about Russia's invasion of our country. Sean Penn is among those who support Ukraine in Ukraine today. Our country is grateful to him for such a show of courage and honesty.” The statement went on to contrast Penn’s “bravery” against the inactivity of some of Ukraine’s Western partners in the face of the military operation launched by Russian President Vladimir Putin. Penn had previously visited Ukraine back in November 2021 to work on another documentary about the Donbass and “Russian aggression.” Back then, he visited the eastern regions of the country and spoke to servicemen. Photos of Penn’s trip were released at the time by the Ukrainian Joint Forces Operation Press Service, where he could be seen dressed in combat gear while filming with his crew. US actor and director Sean Penn visiting the frontline with Russia-backed separatists in Donetsk region. © Handout / Ukrainian Joint Forces Operation press-service / AFP Sean Penn has been involved in many anti-war and humanitarian operations over the years, releasing a 2020 documentary titled ‘Citizen Penn’ about his efforts to set up a non-profit organization in response to the Haiti earthquake in 2010.

title: Sky News reporters forced to end live broadcast and take cover as explosions rock Ukraine
creator: Charlotte Manning
description: Mark Austin and John Sparks were both reporting live from Ukraine.
content: {"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"VideoObject","name":"Metro.co.uk","duration":"T2M42S","thumbnailUrl":"https:\/\/i.dailymail.co.uk\/1s\/2022\/02\/25\/10\/54641771-0-image-a-16_1645784696588.jpg","uploadDate":"2022-02-25T10:22:48+0000","description":"Mark Austin and John Spark both thought it safer to not be outside as the sounds of bombardment drew closer, so they crossed back to the RTS News Channel of the Year's London studios.","contentUrl":"https:\/\/videos.metro.co.uk\/video\/met\/2022\/02\/25\/3948351782153991243\/480x270_MP4_3948351782153991243.mp4","height":270,"width":480} To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video Sky News reporters Mark Austin, in Kyiv, and John Sparks, close to the Russia/Ukraine border in Kharkiv, had to end live broadcasting while reporting on the crisis on Friday morning. Reporter Mark was presenting live from the capital Kyiv, which had been targeted by overnight bombing raids by Russian forces, whereas John was on the ground in Kharkiv – close to the border between the two nations. However, while both men were reporting on the ongoing conflict, they had to take cover and cut back to the studio in London as explosions continued in Ukraine.  John explained: ‘We were going to come to you just a few minutes earlier, but there was a long and loud barrage of what I believe is incoming artillery fire.  ‘It could have been rockets, it felt very close to the centre of… there’s one. Can you hear that Mark?’ The broadcaster went on to describe the area as ‘deserted’ and shared how the heavy snow was muffling the sound of the explosions.  John was taking cover by his hotel building (Picture: Sky News) ‘I’m just going to stop speaking for a minute,’ as the camera panned towards the scene in Kharkiv. John continued: ‘It could be rocket fire, it’s very, very quick and very intense. We’re going to move in. It’s very difficult to see because of the snow. ‘Actually, the snow acts to muffle the sound, this is a very intense bombardment,’ before Mark jumped in: ‘You go, John, I think we should let you go, we’re going to let John Sparks go.’ The reporter and his team had to move inside to take cover (Picture: Sky News) Viewers were then taken to Mark in the capital of Kyiv, who said: ‘Here in Kyiv, the sirens are going, we have seen troops running across the square here, a lot of people moving quite quickly for cover.’ Viewers were shown footage of troops racing around the city, as the reporter continued: ‘We saw them just now, we saw them with ammunition boxes and they appear to be taking some sort of cover. I think it might be a sensible option for us at some stage in the not too distant future. Mark Austin updated viewers on the situation from the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv (Picture: Sky News) ‘In fact, I don’t know whether… I think we’re going to go back to Neil Patterson in London and we will come back to you once we get the all-clear.’ ‘Mark, thank you very much indeed. I’m sure everyone will appreciate the need for our teams on the ground in and around Kyiv and elsewhere to stay safe, so I hope they are getting themselves into those circumstances,’ Neil said. Russia-Ukraine war: Everything you need to know Russian President Vladimir Putin has declared war on Ukraine, with rocket strikes destroying swathes of the country. As of Thursday night, 137 people were killed and a further 316 have have been wounded. However, these numbers are expected to be significantly higher as bombing continued throughout the night and Russian troops have begun to storm the Ukrainian capital city of Kyiv. Prime Minister Boris Johnson described the conflict as a ‘catastrophe for our continent’, and unleashed a ‘massive’ package of sanctions on Russia. But in a chilling warning to world leaders, President Putin said they ‘will face consequences greater than any in history’ if they interfere with his attack. Barack Obama condemns Russia’s ‘brazen attack on the people of Ukraine’ Russia bans UK flights from its airspace in retaliation over sanctions Russia stripped of Champions League final by UEFA My Ukrainian brother was killed on the frontline How to cope with World War Three anxiety Maps reveal how much of London would be vapourised in a nuclear attack Does military conscription still exist in the UK? Follow Metro.co.uk's live blog for rolling coverage of conflict as it happens. Sky’s political correspondent Kate McCann also updated those watching on the situation via her Twitter account, sharing: ‘Our @sparkomat reporting live from Kharkiv as sound of explosions rock city while @markaustintv presents from Kyiv as sirens wail. ‘Both men have just ended live broadcasting to take cover.’ Many viewers below praised the bravery of both men, who are currently based in Ukraine, as one wrote: ‘Brilliant reporting. Keep safe guys.’ A viewer added: ‘I can’t believe what I’m seeing it’s unbelievable. God bless those sky reporters putting themselves in danger like that just to give us the news.’ More: SkySky News’ Kay Burley takes swipe at Adele’s date night outfit over leopard print coatWhen do new Euphoria episodes air in the UK?Chaos on Sky News as teenager shouting expletives ambushes live broadcast by Kate McCann ‘The journalists in the war zone are incredibly brave and follow the best traditions of free, open and truthful journalism. Everyone’s thoughts are with you,’ someone else shared. Another commented: Thoughts are with all of the journalists and their support teams keeping us informed in dangerous circumstances. Thank you but take care – your personal safety is top priority…’ Got a story? title: Russia-Ukraine conflict redraws Europe’s aviation map
creator: RT
description: International airlines avoiding flights over Ukraine amid Russian military operations in the country Read Full Article at RT.com
content: Flight tracker reveals empty skies above Ukraine as military conflict intensifies, UK flights banned from Russian airspace International airlines have stopped flights over Ukrainian territory with the escalation of Russian military activity in the country. A warning has been issued by the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) for commercial flights to avoid Ukrainian airspace as well as areas within 100 nautical miles (185km) of the Russian and Belarus borders. “In particular, there is a risk of both intentional targeting and misidentification of civil aircraft,” the EASA said. “The presence and possible use of a wide range of ground and airborne warfare systems poses a high risk for civil flights operating at all altitudes and flight levels.” In a later-issued update, the regulator advised airlines to “exercise caution” deep inside Russia.Russia suspended domestic flights to and from several airports near its border with Ukraine, including Rostov-on-Don, Krasnodar and Stavropol, until March 2. The step taken “to provide safety” for civil flights left dozens of planes grounded in southern Russia. Read more Ukraine crisis sends global markets plummeting The EASA said Russia’s defense ministry had sent Ukraine an urgent message warning of a high risk to flight safety due to the use of weapons and military equipment, and asked Ukraine’s air traffic control to stop flights. The US Federal Aviation Administration echoed the warnings by expanding an area in or near Ukraine where American airlines cannot operate. According to the flight tracking website FlightRadar24, skies above crisis-torn Ukraine have turned empty as nations halted flights over major safety concerns. As a result, airlines skirted the entire country in crowded corridors to the north and west, leaving a big hole on the aviation map. The data shows that an El Al flight from Tel Aviv to Toronto made a U-turn out of Ukraine’s airspace around the time of its closure, while a LOT Polish Airlines flight from Warsaw to Kyiv also turned back. Kyiv-bound flights operated by Air India and Aegean Airlines soon followed suit. Screenshot © flightradar24.com Ukraine International Airlines diverted one Kyiv-bound flight to Moldova while some of its planes remained grounded in Kyiv. Last week, the carrier sent part of its fleet to safety abroad. Meanwhile, Hungary’s Wizz Air said it was trying to evacuate Ukrainian-based crew, their families and four aircraft. READ MORE: Oil breaches $105 as Russia-Ukraine conflict intensifies Additionally, Russia closed its airspace to British planes on Friday in response to a UK ban on Russian carriers from entering Britain’s airspace or landing on its soil. London included Russian airlines in a package of sanctions imposed to punish Russia for its military attack on Ukraine. The crunch will inevitably cast a shadow over a wider travel demand for the third northern summer in a row, after two years of severe restrictions due to the coronavirus pandemic. For more stories on economy & finance visit RT's business section

title: Ukraine bans transactions in Russian and Belarusian rubles
creator: RT
description: Ukraine’s central bank has banned banks carrying out any foreign exchange transactions using Russian and Belarusian currencies Read Full Article at RT.com
content: The country’s central bank earlier prohibited financial operations on accounts of Russian residents The National Bank of Ukraine (NBU) said on Friday it has prohibited the country's banks from making any foreign exchange transactions using Russian and Belarusian rubles. According to the regulator, Ukrainian banks will also not be able to make any foreign exchange transactions, if the participant involved is an individual or legal entity located in either Russia or Belarus. On Thursday, the Ukraine’s central bank switched to an emergency mode of operation and announced a number of restrictive measures due to martial law being imposed throughout the country. The regulator has banned operations on the accounts of Russian residents and introduced a moratorium on cross-border currency payments. An exception was made to fulfill the tasks of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine. READ MORE: Kiev imposes nighttime curfew In addition, the NBU suspended the activities of the foreign exchange market, with the exception of transactions for the sale of foreign currency. It was forbidden to issue foreign currency in cash to banks, but the measure does not apply to those government-linked institutions. The head of the central bank, Kirill Shevchenko, has assured that the flow of cash to ATMs would not be limited, and non-cash payments were also not subject to restrictions. Ukrainian citizens have flooded the country's ATMs in an attempt to withdraw their money as the conflict with Russia intensifies. For more stories on economy & finance visit RT's business section

title: Ukraine Warned Over Danger Of Russian Spying On ‘Unencrypted’ Telegram

title: UEFA issues decision on Russia and Ukraine
creator: RT
description: UEFA has ordered the Russian and Ukrainian national football teams and clubs from the two countries to play at neutral venues Read Full Article at RT.com
content: UEFA held an emergency meeting on Friday amid the conflict between Russia and Ukraine UEFA has ordered Russian and Ukrainian football teams to play at neutral venues in any competitions organized by the European football governing body “until further notice.” After calling an emergency meeting on Friday, UEFA said its Executive Committee had reached a decision on matches played by the Russian and Ukrainian national teams in its tournaments, as well as clubs from the two countries. “At today’s meeting, the UEFA Executive Committee also decided that Russian and Ukrainian clubs and national teams competing in UEFA competitions will be required to play their home matches at neutral venues until further notice,” read a statement. “The UEFA Executive Committee further determined to remain on standby to convene further extraordinary meetings, on a regular ongoing basis where required, to reassess the legal and factual situation as it evolves and adopt further decisions as necessary.” At the same meeting, UEFA confirmed that it was moving the 2022 Champions League final from the Russian city of St. Petersburg to the Stade de France in Paris. Read more UEFA officially strips Russia of Champions League final The step comes after Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered a special military operation in Donbass and Ukraine. Putin said the step was to defend the populations of the newly-recognized republics of Donetsk and Lugansk, and to “demilitarize” and “de-Nazify” Ukraine. Ukraine and its Western allies have condemned the move, with the fallout continuing to spill over into sport. Many will take UEFA’s actions as an indication that Russia’s 2022 FIFA World Cup playoff match against Poland which is scheduled for March will also be moved from Moscow. READ MORE: Countries in plea to football chiefs over Russia’s ‘alarming’ Ukraine offensive Should Russia emerge from that match, they would face the winner of the meeting between Sweden and Czech Republic later that month, also in a match planned for the Russian capital. The Polish, Czech and Swedish football associations issued a joint statement on Thursday calling on FIFA for the matches to be played at a neutral venue.

title: Putin ‘is not rational’ and ‘won’t stop’ after Ukraine, defence chief warns
creator: Sam Corbishley
description: 'He will use everything in the Baltic States. He doesn’t believe the Baltic States are really countries.'
content: Ben Wallace said he believes Vladimir Putin’s legacy will be ‘isolation’ (Picture: east2west news; TASS/Getty) Vladimir Putin ‘is not rational’ and ‘won’t stop’ after invading Ukraine, Defence Secretary Ben Wallace has warned. Russia had ‘failed to deliver’ on its ‘day one’ objectives, he said, adding that they have lost more than 400 troops as well as a significant airport initially captured by elite Spetsnaz units. Mr Wallace said he believes Mr Putin’s legacy will be ‘isolation’, telling BBC Breakfast that ‘diplomacy is absolutely off the table’. But he insisted British troops will not be sent to fight ‘directly’ with the Russians in order to avoid triggering a ‘war across Europe’. The Cabinet minister told BBC Radio 4’s Today programme: ‘It’s not about risk, as much as I care for my personnel. It’s not about risk. ‘It’s about if we were to directly attack Russian aircraft, we would have a war across Europe.’ {"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"VideoObject","name":"Metro.co.uk","duration":"T1M6S","thumbnailUrl":"https:\/\/i.dailymail.co.uk\/1s\/2022\/02\/25\/07\/54637485-0-image-a-37_1645774986740.jpg","uploadDate":"2022-02-25T07:43:14+0000","description":"'Contrary to great Russian claims...the Russian army has failed to deliver on day one its main objective.'","contentUrl":"https:\/\/videos.metro.co.uk\/video\/met\/2022\/02\/25\/3025838777589518038\/480x270_MP4_3025838777589518038.mp4","height":270,"width":480} To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video Map showing locations of Russian troops and where fighting has broken out (Picture: Metro Graphics) He added: ‘I have said continually for a long time, as has Britain, and the Prime Minister has supported this position, that Putin is not rational. ‘He is trying to invade Ukraine. He won’t stop after he’s … with Ukraine. He will use everything in the Baltic States. He doesn’t believe the Baltic States are really countries. ‘And we will have to stand up to it. Now, I cannot trigger a European war and I won’t trigger a European war. But what I will do is help Ukraine fight every street with every piece of equipment we can get to them, and we will support them, and that is the reality.’ {"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"VideoObject","name":"Metro.co.uk","duration":"T1M8S","thumbnailUrl":"https:\/\/i.dailymail.co.uk\/1s\/2022\/02\/24\/17\/54610703-0-image-a-69_1645722714073.jpg","uploadDate":"2022-02-24T17:11:28+0000","description":"The prime minister called Putin 'a blood-stained aggressor who believes in imperial conquest.'","contentUrl":"https:\/\/videos.metro.co.uk\/video\/met\/2022\/02\/24\/3460875557806559059\/480x270_MP4_3460875557806559059.mp4","height":270,"width":480} To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video Boris Johnson signalled on Thursday that Mr Putin could face war crime charges over the invasion of Ukraine, telling MPs ‘anyone who sends a Russian into battle to kill innocent Ukrainians’ could be brought to court. He also told the Commons that the UK is working with allies to set up a ‘particular international war crimes tribunal for those involved in war crimes in the Ukraine theatre’. On Friday, International Criminal Court (ICC) prosecutor Karim Khan said he had been following the events of the past 24 hours ‘closely’ and ‘with increasing concern’, adding that an investigation into possible war crimes may follow. Speaking to Sky News, Mr Wallace said he would expect Mr Putin to be ‘held to account’ if he committed a war crime. He said: ‘If President Putin commits a war crime, then, just as I do if I were to commit a war crime, I should expect to be held to account.’ More: RussiaRussian platoon 'surrenders saying they didn't think they had been sent to kill'Turkish ship hit by bomb off coast of UkraineUkraine expected to fall by Monday despite entire country being mobilised Asked if Mr Putin’s actions already constituted a war crime, he said: ‘I’m not, I’m afraid, an international lawyer. ‘I couldn’t tell you the difference between breaking international law insofar as directing your forces to invade another country, versus a war crime – eg. things like genocide, and indeed, you know, torture, etc. ‘I wouldn’t want to speculate the differences. What I would say is he’s clearly broken international law, he’s occupying or trying to occupy a sovereign country who made one mistake in his eyes. Their mistake in his eyes was not to choose the Kremlin as a way for their future. And that’s all they have done.’ Russia-Ukraine war: Everything you need to know Russian President Vladimir Putin has declared war on Ukraine, with rocket strikes destroying swathes of the country. As of Thursday night, 137 people were killed and a further 316 have have been wounded. However, these numbers are expected to be significantly higher as bombing continued throughout the night and Russian troops have begun to storm the Ukrainian capital city of Kyiv. Prime Minister Boris Johnson described the conflict as a ‘catastrophe for our continent’, and unleashed a ‘massive’ package of sanctions on Russia. But in a chilling warning to world leaders, President Putin said they ‘will face consequences greater than any in history’ if they interfere with his attack. Barack Obama condemns Russia’s ‘brazen attack on the people of Ukraine’ Russia bans UK flights from its airspace in retaliation over sanctions Russia stripped of Champions League final by UEFA My Ukrainian brother was killed on the frontline How to cope with World War Three anxiety Maps reveal how much of London would be vapourised in a nuclear attack Does military conscription still exist in the UK? Follow Metro.co.uk's live blog for rolling coverage of conflict as it happens. Get in touch with our news team by emailing us at webnews@metro.co.uk. For more stories like this, check our news page.

title: Piers Morgan suggests ‘megalomaniac gangster thug’ Putin wouldn’t have invaded Ukraine if Donald Trump was still president
creator: Mel Evans
description: 'Putin has to lose, he has to lose badly.'
content: {"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"VideoObject","name":"Metro.co.uk","duration":"T55S","thumbnailUrl":"https:\/\/i.dailymail.co.uk\/1s\/2022\/02\/25\/09\/54640063-0-image-a-46_1645780323558.jpg","uploadDate":"2022-02-25T09:12:04+0000","description":"'He's a supreme narcissist. He's a dangerous guy. He's a killer.'","contentUrl":"https:\/\/videos.metro.co.uk\/video\/met\/2022\/02\/25\/7388464587359801325\/480x270_MP4_7388464587359801325.mp4","height":270,"width":480} To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video Piers Morgan has once again shared his hot take on the Russian invasion of Ukraine, insisting he doesn’t believe Vladimir Putin would have gone ahead with the attack if Donald Trump was still US President. To him, Trump was ‘too unpredictable’ for Putin to take such a risk. It comes at Russian missile strikes on Ukraine continued through the night, including on the capital Kyiv. As of Thursday night, 137 were killed and 316 wounded, but there are fears this number will have risen significantly in fresh fighting. Sharing his thoughts on Friday morning, the former Good Morning Britain presenter slammed the response from other countries, branding Germany’s ‘frankly pathetic’ and accused others of ‘punishing Putin’s oligarch friends’ instead. He also heavily criticised Putin, and after earlier ripping apart the ‘bully-boy’ leader in a blistering takedown, he added to it during an appearance on Australia’s Today show. When asked by hosts Karl Stefanovic and Allison Langdon for his musings, he said: ‘My thoughts are this has been coming, Vladimir Putin is a KGB gangster thug, he wants to restore the Soviet Union to, in his eyes, its former glory, and it’s going to criminally invade countries until we stop him.’ Piers doesn’t think Putin would have invaded under Trump (Picture: Alexei Nikolsky\\\\TASS via Getty Images) Piers went on to suggest Putin is ‘gonna take Ukraine, I would imagine quite quickly’, adding: ‘Because nobody has the military will or desire to try and stop him there,’ noting the actions taken by leaders so far seemed to be ‘punishing his rich mates’. He went on: ‘How does that stop someone with Putin’s megalomaniac ambition? He’s a supreme narcissist, he’s a dangerous guy, he’s a killer and what he’s doing in Ukraine is an absolute disgrace. ‘The Ukrainian people deserve a lot more than what they’re getting right now from a tepid, timid world looking at this and going “isn’t this awful, let’s punish some of his oligarch friends”.’ Asked who had the might to stand up to Putin, Piers conceded it was America, but that he didn’t believe President Joe Biden had the power, especially following the withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan last year which, to Piers, ‘handed the country to the Taliban’. Trump was ‘too unpredictable’ (Picture: Getty Images) He said: ‘Putin’s testing not just the world, but essentially, he’s testing America, have you got the stomach for the fight,’ before adding China ‘will be watching this’ situation unfold as well, wondering whether the response from the US will determine if they try to ‘take Taiwan’. Piers explained: ‘Then we’re into a world war situation, which would be catastrophic. The world has to come together. ‘Putin has to lose, he has to lose badly, he has to be shamed and humiliated and kicked out of Ukraine with his tail between his legs. ‘I just worry who has the will to do it?’ As the topic of nuclear weapons came up, the journalist hoped ‘cooler heads will prevail’ before it comes to that, but described Putin as ‘a dictator in the classic form’: ‘He wants to restore the Soviet Union, he wants all those countries back under his power. ‘What we’re seeing now is the manifestation of weak policies, an overreliance on their energy, which gives him a financial hold… ‘The way Germany has responded has been frankly pathetic, because they feel financially paralysed by their reliance on Russian energy.’ Piers didn’t hold back (Picture: NINE) Talk then turned to Trump, and how the former US President, who lost the 2020 election to Biden, would have responded to Putin and the invasion of Ukraine, after he suggested it ‘wouldn’t happen on his watch’. ‘He may have a point,’ Piers said. ‘He’s said some stupid things in the last week about Putin being a genius, but one thing he was probably right about was that there was an unpredictability about Trump that deterred people like Putin and North Korea from doing anything because they thought “we’re not quite sure how he’ll respond”. ‘There’s no unpredictability from Joe Biden, he’s an old guy who’s showing his age, I think he’s had a disastrous first year in office and what he did in Afghanistan was rank cowardice.’ Piers went on: ‘To be fair to Trump, and it’s difficult to be fair to Trump…I think on the foreign stage he was not a warmonger. Trump didn’t go to war anywhere, he always thought wars were a senseless waste of money… ‘Would it have happened if Trump had been president? I doubt it. ‘I doubt Putin would have done this. I think he’s done it because he senses in Biden a weak leader at a weak time.’ Piers’s words come after troops poured in from the Crimean peninsula and assaulted border guards head on along the eastern and northern borders. Video footage shows tanks forcing their way through border checkpoints on Thursday morning, with Ukrainian border force claiming that a number of guards were injured. More: Donald TrumpTrump is a 'nauseating, fearful pig' for calling Putin 'pretty smart': Biden staffer saysDonald Trump says Putin is a 'genius' after 10,000 Russian troops invade UkraineDonald Trump's Truth Social app 'prohibits disparaging him' despite 'free speech' promise Meanwhile, more than 1,400 people in Russia were arrested during anti-war demonstrations, with pictures showing them being dragged away by police. US and Ukrainian officials say Russia aims to capture Kyiv and topple the government, which Putin regards as a puppet of the United States.

title: Ukraine’s nuclear agency finds Chernobyl radiation rise
creator: Associated Press
description: Ukraine’s nuclear energy regulatory agency says that higher than usual gamma radiation levels have been detected in the area near the decommissioned Chernobyl nuclear plant, after it was seized by the Russian military.
content: Ukraine’s nuclear energy regulatory agency says that higher than usual gamma radiation levels have been detected in the area near the decommissioned Chernobyl nuclear plant, after it was seized by the Russian military.

title: The View’s Joy Behar’s ‘tone deaf’ remarks Ukraine war will disrupt her holiday unsurprisingly sparks uproar
creator: Meghna Amin
description: Get the tiny violins out.
content: {"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"VideoObject","name":"Metro.co.uk","duration":"T34S","thumbnailUrl":"https:\/\/i.dailymail.co.uk\/1s\/2022\/02\/25\/08\/54639567-0-image-a-43_1645779550576.jpg","uploadDate":"2022-02-25T08:59:22+0000","description":"More than 130 Ukrainians have been killed on day one.","contentUrl":"https:\/\/videos.metro.co.uk\/video\/met\/2022\/02\/25\/2522658484137969592\/480x270_MP4_2522658484137969592.mp4","height":270,"width":480} To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video While the world is watching the Ukraine crisis unfold and praying for those caught up in the chaos, Joy Behar has instead shown concern for her own holidays. The View host, 79, stirred outrage with tone-deaf comments only hours after Putin ordered Russian troops to invade Ukraine. On Thursday’s edition of the talk-show, co-host Sunny Hostin, 53, was sharing some facts about the warfare in Eastern Europe, as thousands of Ukraine people planned their evacuations from what would later become a warzone. Yet Behar clearly missed on reading the room, and led the discussion towards her plans to travel to Italy, a country 1,500 miles away from the unfolding situation. Hostin began: ‘Estimates are 50,000 Ukranians will be dead or wounded and this is going to start a refugee crisis in Europe. We’re talking about 5million people that are going to be displaced. ‘It’s heartbreaking to hear what is going to happen.’ But Behar avoided further commentary on eastern Europe, and turned her focus west: ‘I’m scared of what’s going to happen in western Europe, too. ‘You plan a trip, you want to go there, I’ve wanted to go to Italy for four years and I haven’t been able to make it because of the pandemic and now this. ‘It’s like, what’s gonna happen there?’ Behar’s comments sparked outrage on social media, with one viewer writing: ‘Did Putin even stop to think how his invasion would affect Joy Behar’s trip to Italy?’ Another joked: ‘You almost have to respect Joy Behar’s unwavering commitment toward ensuring that boomers are the most hated generation alive.’ Behar’s concerns for her trip to Italy sparked outrage on social media (Picture: The View / ABC) A third added: ‘The true horror of the worldwide pandemic and Russia invading Ukraine? Joy Behar hasn’t been able to take her trip to Italy. Thoughts and Prayers for Joy. We hope she makes it through this tragedy.’ One user commented: ‘Is it possible for Joy Behar to be any more tone deaf?’ Will send her some positive vibes while I play my tiny violin. pic.twitter.com/4PTVsmc4qu— LiketheHurricane (@CELPbytheSea) February 25, 2022 pic.twitter.com/SYXQyRyVFM — Rachel Dzanashvili (@rachel_dz) February 25, 2022 Someone need to start a GoFundMe to send joy to Europe. — 🦉 (@Marry_Jake) February 24, 2022 Please Make A Wish get in touch with @JoyVBehar so we can make this Italy trip happen — Crypto Rich – Cash Broke (@MasseyJos) February 25, 2022 She can’t catch a break. First, the Whoopi stress & now her Italy trip in jeopardy? That’s a lot on her plate — Roger the Dodger (@RogerThomas1288) February 25, 2022 Behar is the show’s longest running host (Picture: Lou Rocco/ABc via Getty Images) This recent spate of controversy surrounding the American talk show follows Whoopi Goldberg’s recent suspension for making comments that the Holocause ‘wasn’t about race.’ More: UkraineRussian platoon 'surrenders saying they didn't think they had been sent to kill'Turkish ship hit by bomb off coast of UkraineWorld turns yellow and blue in solidarity with Ukraine following Russian invasion The Sister Act star, 66, has since apologised for her remarks, in which she claimed the Holocaust was actually about ‘man’s inhumanity to man,’ but received a lot of criticism. Goldberg has hosted the view since 2007, and currently appears alongside with the longest-running host Behar who has hosted all 23 seasons since the show’s premiere in 1997, as well as Hostin and Sarah Haines, with Ana Navarro as a guest host The View airs weekdays on ABC in the US. title: We are ready to bear full travel expenses of students stuck in Ukraine: Telangana government
creator: Edex Live
description: KT Rama Rao made an appeal to Foreign Minister S Jaishankar on the plight of students from the state stranded in Ukraine
content: The government of Telangana on Friday offered to bear full travel expenses of students from Telangana stranded in Ukraine. State Minister for Industries and Information Technology KT Rama Rao urged the central government to arrange for special aircraft to bring the students home. He made an appeal to Foreign Minister S Jaishankar on the plight of students from the state stranded in Ukraine. "We appeal to Govt of India to arrange for special aircrafts & Telangana Govt is ready to bear the full travel expenses for these students so we can bring them home safe & soonest," tweeted Rama Rao. Earlier, responding to a tweet by a relative of one of the 20 students stranded in Ukraine, the state minister requested the Indian embassy in Ukraine to reach out to them. One Epuri Raghavendra tweeted that 20 Telangana students, including his brother, are waiting for help in Vinnytsia. He wrote that students are very scared and helplines in Ukraine are not responsive. They disconnected the call by saying present location of students is very faraway for help. The Telangana government has set up helplines at Telangana Bhavan New Delhi and State Secretariat Hyderabad to help the students and citizens of the state who are stranded in Ukraine. Chief Secretary Somesh Kumar on Friday held a teleconference with the Principal Secretary, General Administration, Vikas Raj and Resident Commissioner Telangana Bhavan Gaurav Uppal and took stock of the situation. The helplines have so far received 75 calls. The chief secretary said that the state government is in constant touch with the External Affairs ministry, Government of India and taking all steps to ensure the safety and security of the Telangana people. Efforts are also being made to ensure that all the stranded persons are evacuated and they reach the state safely, he said.

title: Situation tense, uncertain: Indian envoy in Ukraine tells stranded nationals
creator: Sentinel Digital Desk
description: The situation is highly tense and very uncertain and this of course is causing a lot of anxiety
content: NEW DELHI: The situation is highly tense and very uncertain and this of course is causing a lot of anxiety, said Indian Ambassador to Ukraine on Thursday reaching out to stranded Indian nationals.Partha Satpathy, Indian Ambassador to Ukraine, said, "I am reaching out to you from Kiev. Today early morning, we all woke up with the news that Ukraine is under attack." The air space is closed, railway schedules are in a flux and roads are crammed, he said requesting everyone to stay calm and face the situation with fortitude. The Embassy continues to remain open and operate in Kiev, Satpathy said. He urged Indian nationals to please stay wherever they are, in their familiar locations. "Those who are in transit, please return to your familiar places of habitation. Those who are stranded here in Kiev, please get in touch with your friends and colleagues in Kiev, universities and other community members, so that you can temporarily lodge there," he said. The Ambassador said, "We have already reached out to the Indian Diaspora and have requested them to assist to the best of our abilities." He said that he is inundated with calls, so is the Embassy and they are doing their best to help. "If there is a critical emergency, contact us on the emergency lines provided. Please follow our social media platforms (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and Website) for any updates that we will be putting out," he stated. As of now, Indian government are seized of the situation and working on a mission mode to find a solution to this difficult situation, he added. Earlier in the day, the Indian embassy in Ukraine announced that they are making alternative arrangements for evacuation of stranded nationals. The Ministry of External Affairs in touch with all the neighbouring countries surrounding Ukraine to even evacuate Indian citizens. Many citizens who were to fly back to India were left at the airport after closure of Ukrainian airspace following Russia's Vladimir Putin announcement of a military operation in Ukraine. (IANS) Also Read:  Russia-Ukraine Crisis: Anonymous Declares 'Cyber War' Against Vladimir Putin's GovernmentAlso watch:

title: Nearly 2,500 students from Gujarat stranded in Ukraine, Centre to ensure safe return
creator: Edex Live
description: The opposition Congress targeted the BJP government in the state, accusing it of inaction and delay in evacuating students and other Indian citizens stuck in the eastern European country
content: Nearly 2,500 students from Gujarat are stranded in Ukraine amid Russia's military operation, a state minister said on Friday. Talking to reporters, Education Minister Jitu Vaghani said Chief Minister Bhupendra Patel has been in touch with the Centre to ensure the safe return of the stranded students to the state. The opposition Congress targeted the BJP government in the state, accusing it of inaction and delay in evacuating students and other Indian citizens stuck in the eastern European country, while the ruling party said the Centre is doing everything possible for the safe return of the Indians, including the students from the state. "Nearly 2,500 students from Gujarat are in Ukraine at present. The Indian government has been concerned about all its citizens since the very beginning. CM Bhupendra Patel is in constant touch with External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar and the Prime Minister's Office to ensure safe return of Gujarati students and other citizens from the state, who are based in different parts of Ukraine," Vaghani said. He said that as instructed by the chief minister, state Chief Secretary Pankaj Kumar spoke to the Foreign Secretary on Thursday and the state government has also opened a control room to provide guidance and information about the latest situation in Ukraine. "Apart from the contact numbers provided by the Centre, people living in Gujarat can dial 079-23251900 to seek any information or help. I urge people stuck in Ukraine to be in touch with the Indian Embassy. I am confident that the Indian government will find a way to evacuate Indians just like we did in the past," the minister said. Unhappy with the Centre's response to the crisis, Congress spokesperson Shaktisinh Gohil on Friday asked the Modi government to come out of the election mode. "The Congress had asked the Centre to start the process of evacuation a week ago. But it did nothing. The BJP government should come out of the election mode and think about those who are still stranded. As an alternative to the air route, we can evacuate Indians by shifting them to European countries using roads," Gohil said. Several students from Gujarat who are studying in Ukraine have been making desperate appeal for evacuation for the last few days. Russian forces on Thursday launched a military operation against Ukraine following weeks of tension between the two neighbouring countries.

title: Dancing With The Stars’ Peta Murgatoyd asks for prayers for struggling husband Maksim Chmerkovskiy who is stuck in Ukraine
creator: Rachael O'Connor
description: 'Please pray that he comes home soon.'
content: Dancing With The Stars’ Maksim Chmerkovskiy is trapped in Ukraine, with wife Peta Murgatoyd asking for prayers (Picture: Rex) Peta Murgatoyd has asked for prayers for her husband Maksim Chmerkovskiy who is stranded in Ukraine as Russia continue their full-scale invasion on the country. The Dancing With The Stars legend shared a video from Kyiv on Thursday morning where, clearly frightened and emotional, he said ‘no one saw this coming’. Russia launched airstrikes across Ukraine in the early hours of Thursday morning, with President Vladimir Putin warning world leaders that they will ‘face consequences greater than any in history’ if they interfere. Maksim, 42, is married to fellow Dancing With The Stars professional Peta, and late on Thursday night, as fighting continued across the country, Peta asked for prayers from her followers. Taking to Instagram, the 35-year-old said: ‘Please pray for my husband Maks. ‘I don’t usually ask these things from my social media network, however today is extremely hard and the next few days will be even harder. https://www.instagram.com/p/CaYF5Owvj9X/ ‘My pain is overwhelming and I’m struggling but you sending your positive light and love to him would mean the world to me. Truly, I wish for nothing more.’ Peta went on to say she didn’t have answers to the ‘details’ that many are asking for, but assured fans that Maks is ‘safe right now’. ‘Please pray that he comes home soon,’ Peta went on. ‘Please pray that he has a swift, safe exit.’ She added: ‘Please pray for Ukraine and the innocent civilians who’s lives are being greatly uprooted (sic). ‘I grew to love this country the couple of times I visited and they’re in an unfathomable situation.’ Maksim shared tearful videos from Kyiv on Thursday (Picture: Instagram) Peta’s message has led to an outpouring of love from across the world, with American sports presenter Erin Andrews, actor Nick Viall, and Selling Sunset star Chrisell Strause among those sending prayer emojis. Fellow Dancing With The Stars professional Keo Motsepe said: ‘Sending you sooooo much love and prayers to u an family (sic)’ while Lindsay Arnold said: ‘Love you so much Pete ❤️ thinking of you all and sending prayers your way’. On Thursday, a devastated Maksim shared videos from Kyiv as he looked out across the capital from a balcony, while sirens could be heard ringing out around him. In one video, Maksim teared up as he panned his camera along the city as sirens rung out incessantly. https://www.instagram.com/tv/CaXEYnAgr_b/?utm_source=ig_embed His voice broke as he continued: ‘Honestly, I’m getting really emotional, it’s been a little difficult. You know me, I stay strong and I don’t show it. ‘But I want to go back home. And I realize that I have the way to. I realize that I have a different passport, and my family is far away. What I’m realising is that my friends, whose kids are here and whose moms and dads are here, they can’t just escape.’ Peta and Maksim share a young son together (Picture: starmaxinc.com/REX/Shutterstock) The dad-of-one – who shares son Shai with his co-star – explained that he is ‘about to go into a bomb shelter because s**t is going down,’ and insisted that ‘this is not the way we do things’. More: ShowbizSean Penn randomly turns up at Ukraine president's briefing on Russian invasionKim Kardashian says Kanye West’s Instagram posts 'caused emotional distress'Strictly's Motsi Mabuse fearful for Ukrainian husband's parents amid Russian invasion Troops from Russia crossed the border into Ukraine on Thursday after President Vladimir Putin gave the order for his invasion to begin. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has unveiled severe sanctions against Russian banks, oligarchs and companies following the invasion. Got a story? title: KTR urges centre to arrange special aircraft for Telangana students stranded in Ukraine
creator: Roja Mayabrahma
description: TRS working president and minister KT Rama Rao on Thursday appealed to the external affairs minister S Jaishankar to arrange a special aircraft to the Telangana students stranded in Ukraine.
content: TRS working president and minister KT Rama RaoTRS working president and minister KT Rama RaoTRS working president and minister KT Rama Rao on Thursday appealed to the external affairs minister S Jaishankar to arrange a special aircraft to the Telangana students stranded in Ukraine. The minister said that the government is ready to bear all the travel expenses for the students so they can be brought home safe and soonest. "Humble appeal to Sri @DrSJaishankar Ji on the plight of students from Telangana stranded in Ukraine. We appeal to Govt of India to arrange for special aircrafts & Telangana Govt is ready to bear the full travel expenses for these students so we can bring them home safe & soonest," the minister tweeted on Friday.Even on Thursday, the minister urged the union minister to ensure the safety of Indian students in Ukraine in the times of distress. "Have been receiving several messages from anxious parents of students. Hope Govt of India can work through diplomatic channels & reassure all Indians at the earliest," he said.Meanwhile, the Telangana government has set up helplines in Delhi and Hyderabad for the students and citizens, stranded in Ukraine. The stranded citizens of Telangana can reach on +91 7042566955, +91 9949351270 and +91 9654663661.

title: Ukraine president says he’s being hunted by troops as Russia’s ‘number one target’
creator: Sabrina Johnson
description: Volodymyr Zelensky has vowed to stay in Kyiv.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky has vowed to stay in Kyiv (Picture: AFP / Alamy) The Ukrainian president said he knows he is Russia’s ‘number one target’ and has information ‘subversive groups’ are approaching the capital of Kyiv. Volodymyr Zelensky, 44, addressed his nation last night following the first day of the Russian invasion. Speaking from Kyiv he said he understood he and his family are key targets for Russia, which he said wants to ‘destroy Ukraine politically by destroying the head of state’. US and Ukrainian officials say Russia aims to capture Kyiv and topple the government, which Putin regards as a puppet of the United States. Mr Zelensky said his government has intelligence ‘subversive groups’ are encroaching on the capital while American officials say the city ‘could well be under siege’. Addressing his nation, Mr Zelensky said he understood Russian troops were coming for him but vowed to stay in Kyiv. ‘[The] enemy has marked me down as the number one target,’ he said in a video message. ‘My family is the number two target. They want to destroy Ukraine politically by destroying the head of state.’ ‘I will stay in the capital. My family is also in Ukraine.’ Ukrainian soldiers are taking up positions in the centre of Kyiv as they prepare to defend the city from Russian forces (Picture: AFP via Getty Images) {"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"VideoObject","name":"Metro.co.uk","duration":"T1M25S","thumbnailUrl":"https:\/\/i.dailymail.co.uk\/1s\/2022\/02\/25\/07\/54636905-0-image-a-31_1645772934018.jpg","uploadDate":"2022-02-25T07:06:58+0000","description":"Ukraine's president addressed the nation unshaven and in a t-shirt, as he feared for his family's safety.","contentUrl":"https:\/\/videos.metro.co.uk\/video\/met\/2022\/02\/25\/5079499558554745846\/480x270_MP4_5079499558554745846.mp4","height":270,"width":480} To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video Asked if he was worried about Mr Zelensky’s safety, US secretary of state Antony Blinken told CBS: ‘To the best of my knowledge, president Zelensky remains in Ukraine at his post, and of course we’re concerned for the safety of all of our friends in Ukraine – government officials and others.’ Heavy explosions rattled Kyiv in the early hours of this morning as the second day of the incursion began with a missile barrage. A senior Ukrainian official said Russian forces would enter areas just outside the capital later today and Ukrainian troops were defending positions on four fronts despite being outnumbered. Mr Zelensky’s top diplomat Dmytro Kuleba said ‘horrific rocket strikes’ have hit Kyiv, likening the bombardment to the city’s 1941 shelling by Nazi Germany. He has appealed to global leaders to do more than impose severe sanctions on Russia and has called for defence assistance. Firefighters try to extinguish a blaze at a damaged residential building at Koshytsa Street in Kyiv (Picture: Anadolu Agency via Getty Images) ‘If you don’t help us now, if you fail to offer a powerful assistance to Ukraine, tomorrow the war will knock on your door,’ said the leader, who cut diplomatic ties with Moscow yesterday, declared martial law and ordered a full military mobilisation. Ukraine’s army stands at 250,000 servicemen with 140,000 reservists. The president has tasked the military’s general staff with determining the number of people eligible for service and the number of reservists as well as the order of the call-up. He called those that had lost their lives in the invasion ‘heroes’ and also said hundreds more have been wounded. Mr Zelensky said that despite Russia’s claim it is attacking only military targets, civilian sites also have been struck. People gather in an air raid shelter in Kyiv (Picture: Reuters) ‘They’re killing people and turning peaceful cities into military targets. It’s foul and will never be forgiven,’ he said. Thousands of Ukrainians spent last night taking shelter in Kyiv’s subway network fearing Russia would bomb the city overnight. Air raid sirens wailed over Kyiv amid unconfirmed reports that a Russian plane had been shot down and crashed into a building. ‘Nobody believed that this war would start and that they would take Kyiv directly,’ said Anton Mironov, one of those spending the night in the Soviet-era metro network. ‘I feel mostly fatigue. None of it feels real.’ Get in touch with our news team by emailing us at webnews@metro.co.uk. For more stories like this, check our news page.

title: Barack Obama condemns Russia’s ‘brazen attack on the people of Ukraine’
creator: Sam Corbishley
description: The former US president said people 'need to loudly and clearly condemn Russia’s actions and offer support for the Ukrainian people'.
content: Barack Obama said Vladimir Putin had acted ‘in violation of international law and basic principles of human decency’ (Picture: Getty; AP) Barack Obama has condemned Vladimir Putin’s decision to invade Ukraine – days after his successor Donald Trump branded the Russian president a ‘genius’. The former US president released a statement on Thursday, hours after Russia began its offensive by land, air, and sea following a declaration of war. Mr Obama accused Russia of launching ‘a brazen attack on the people of Ukraine, in violation of international law and basic principles of human decency’. He went on: ‘Russia did so not because Ukraine posed a threat to Russia, but because the people of Ukraine chose a path of sovereignty, self-determination, and democracy. ‘For exercising rights that should be available to all people and nations, Ukrainians now face a brutal onslaught that is killing innocents and displacing untold numbers of men, women, and children.’ Mr Obama added: ‘People of conscience around the world need to loudly and clearly condemn Russia’s actions and offer support for the Ukrainian people. ‘And every American, regardless of party, should support President Biden’s efforts, in coordination with our closest allies, to impose hard-hitting sanctions on Russia – sanctions that impose a real price on Russia’s autocratic elites. ‘There may be some economic consequences to such sanctions, given Russia’s significant role in world energy markets. But that’s a price we should be willing to pay to take a stand on the side of freedom.’ Mr Obama’s statement in full (Picture: Barack Obama/Twitter) Another former president, George W Bush, called Russia’s attack on Ukraine ‘constitutes the gravest security crisis on the European continent since World War II’. He said: ‘I join the international community in condemning Vladimir Putin’s unprovoked and unjustified invasion of Ukraine. ‘We cannot tolerate the authoritarian bullying and danger that Putin poses. Ukraine is our friend and democratic ally, and deserves our full support during this most difficult time.’ Their strong condemnations of Mr Putin contrasted with the remarks of Mr Trump, who called the Russian leader a ‘genius’. He told the conservative ‘Clay Travis and Buck Sexton Show’ earlier this week: ‘I said, this is genius: Putin declares a big portion . . . of Ukraine as independent. How smart is that? And he’s gonna go in and be a peacekeeper. That’s [the] strongest peace force.’ More: Donald TrumpTrump is a 'nauseating, fearful pig' for calling Putin 'pretty smart': Biden staffer saysDonald Trump says Putin is a 'genius' after 10,000 Russian troops invade UkraineDonald Trump's Truth Social app 'prohibits disparaging him' despite 'free speech' promise Mr Trump has not spoken since the invasion started. Leaders of the 30 Nato allied nations will meet on Friday, current US President Joe Biden confirmed, as they come under pressure to go even further than sanctions already announced to hit the Kremlin. In the US, Mr Biden also announced extra sanctions to target Russian banks, oligarchs and high-tech sectors, with more troops deployed to Germany to bolster Nato. ‘Putin is the aggressor,’ Mr Biden said. ‘Putin chose this war, and now he and his country will bear the consequences.’ Get in touch with our news team by emailing us at webnews@metro.co.uk. For more stories like this, check our news page.

title: YS Jagan talks to Union Foreign Minister for repatriation of Telugu students from Ukraine
creator: Pavan Kumar Bandari
description: Chief Minister YS Jagan Mohan Reddy phoned Union Foreign Minister Jayashankar on Friday and discussed on the safe repatriation of Telugu students stranded in Ukraine.
content: Chief Minister YS Jagan Mohan Reddy Chief Minister YS Jagan Mohan Reddy Chief Minister YS Jagan Mohan Reddy phoned Union Foreign Minister Jayashankar on Friday and discussed on the safe repatriation of Telugu students stranded in Ukraine. It is suggested that appropriate action be taken to this extent.However, Jayasankar told the Chief Minister that the centre is taking all possible measures. He said that steps would be taken to relocate students from Ukraine to other parts of the world by special flights and later shift them to India.Earlier on Friday, Chief Minister YS Jagan Mohan Reddy held a review meeting with his superiors on the safe repatriation of Telugu people stranded in Ukraine. CM Jagan also wrote a letter to the Foreign Minister asking him to take steps to bring back the Telugu.Meanwhile, Telugu students in Ukraine are facing difficulties in the wake of Russian attacks. It remains to be seen how long these attacks will last and how the situation will change. The Telugu students there told the hat the impact of the Russian attacks had begun, that the main roads had been closed and that the ATMs were being closed.Nearly 20,000 Indian students are studying at the universities of Zephrozia, Kyiv, Kharkiv and Mariappal in Ukraine. It is estimated that there are more than 3 thousand people from Andhra Pradesh and Telangana states. Most of them are students doing MBBS. Ukraine's climatic conditions are similar to those in India, where students are better educated. However, the problem for Telugu students started in the wake of the Russian attacks on Ukraine. The parents are appealing to politicians to make arrangements to bring their children safely.

title: Russia And Ukraine: Different Nations Or One Entity Divided By History?
creator: Sentinel Digital Desk
description: Both of the Slavic race, and the Orthodox Christian Church, Russians and Ukrainians (or at least half of them) have been linked since Kievan Rus emerged in the 9th century.
content: Moscow: Just ahead of the military action in Ukraine, Russian President Vladimir Putin had, in an address to his nation (and the world), termed Ukrainian statehood a "fiction" and attributed the very existence of modern Ukraine to Bolshevik leaders in wake of the 1917 Revolution.Political rhetoric may not need to be accurate, but there is no doubt that Russia and Ukraine have long and intertwined historical and cultural affinities. For starters, the first names of both the Russian and Ukrainian Presidents - Vladimir and Volodymyr (Zelensky) - are variants. And then, guess where famous Russians such as the writer Nikolai Gogol, and General Secretary Leonid Brezhnev were born? Or where did Nikita Khrushchev, who can be blamed for a lot of the present-day problems in this connection - handing over the Crimean Peninsula from Russia to Ukraine in the 1950s - begin his career? Both Russia and Ukraine can be said to have emerged as independent nations after the dissolution of the Soviet Union on December 25, 1991, but the latter was - along with Belarus (or Byelorussia then) - a separate member of the United Nations from its inception after World War II. Both of the Slavic race, and the Orthodox Christian Church, Russians and Ukrainians (or at least half of them) have been linked since Kievan Rus emerged in the 9th century, and both claim it as a birthplace of their modern cultures, religion, and language, with the Russian state centred around Moscow only coming up a few centuries later. After the breakup of Kievan Rus in the 12th century and consequent subjugation by the Mongols, there was no Ukrainian "state" as such till the 20th century. The historical reality, spanning a millennium of changing religions, borders and peoples, and politics, is much more complex, if not confusing - and explains why the eastern and western parts of Ukraine are different in culture and even religion. Much of the latter was even a part of Poland - for about 20 years - following World War I, and before that, under the Austro-Hungarian Hapsburg Empire. The rest was a part of the Tsarist empire - and then the Soviet Union. Any good history book can tell you about the tortuous fate of the territories that comprise present-day Ukraine, in the last five centuries or so under various empires and regimes, there are some more nuances that need to be explored. First, despite historically close political and cultural ties, Ukraine was never Russified to the same extent as Belarus (where Belarusian is now spoken only by about 10 per cent of the population). And then, the Ukrainians are not enthused by the autocratic rule of both the Tsars and the Commissars - especially, Stalin, who is blamed by them for the devastating famine caused by the collectivisation drive in the early 1930s, which is still remembered as the "Holodomor" (death by hunger) that left at least 4 million of them dead. Then, take the name of Ukraine itself - it is derived from "krai", an Eastern Slavic-origin word that can mean both "edge" or "borderland" - still in use in Russia, as in Primorsky Krai - the southeastern-most part of Russia, bordering China and North Korea. A section of scholars, however, contend that "krai" can also mean "country" or, even, "homeland". Historically, Ukraine was sometimes referred to as "the Ukraine", but this is considered incorrect or even offensive now - as U.S. President George H.W. Bush once learned to his cost. The problem is rooted in grammar. In Eastern Slavic (both the Russian and Ukrainian languages), the preposition "na" (as in the English transliteration) is used to refer to regions or areas, while "v" (transliterated) is used to refer to proper nouns or definite locations. Until 1991, Ukraine could be referred to using "na", but most Ukrainians have now switched to "v", but the Russians stubbornly still use "na". This leads to Ukrainians thinking that the "na" user doesn't consider Ukraine a "real" country, although there are some Ukrainians who use "n?" either out of habit, or they just don't see it as an issue. A complicated relationship, made more so by present events, the Russian-Ukrainian connection seems to keep on being interesting - not to mention impactful - for the wider world.Also read: Ukraine Asks Its Citizens To Leave Russia ImmediatelyAlso watch:
